title: Deglet Nour
text:
Deglet Nour also spelled Deglet Noor (Modern <a href="Arabic">Arabic</a>: ; from Classical Arabic دقْلَة النُور :daqlatu (a)n-nūr - literally, "date-palm of light"; "heavenly date"; from Classical Arabic daqal, a kind of date palm) named also Royal Dates—is a <a href="cultivar">cultivar</a> of the <a href="Phoenix%20dactylifera">date palm</a> which originated in the oasis of <a href="Tolga%2C%20Algeria">Tolga</a> in <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a>. Commonly referred to as the "queen of all dates", the authentic North-african Deglet Nour date has a soft touch, a translucent light color and a soft <a href="honey">honey</a>-like taste, characteristics which distinguish it from other dates.
Deglet Nours are popular in <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a>, <a href="Libya">Libya</a>, <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>, and the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> where it is grown in inland oases and is the chief export cultivar.
Deglet Nour is one of hundreds of cultivars of <a href="Phoenix%20dactylifera">date palm</a> but is, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (<a href="FAO">FAO</a>), the leading date in terms of export value.
Origins.
Several old books provide evidence that the Deglet Nour date was first grown in Algeria. Among them are "Le palmier-dattier" by Pierre Munier, "L'Algérie: un siècle de colonisation française" by Félix Falck, "Un voyage au pays des dattes" by Jean-Henri Fabre as well as "le Bulletin de la Société botanique de France". Munier states that the fruit was introduced at the end of the 13th century and at the beginning of the 14th century from the oasis of <a href="Tolga%2C%20Algeria">Tolga</a> to the neighboring areas of <a href="Biskra">Biskra</a> and <a href="Oued%20Righ">Oued Righ</a> in <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a>, before being brought to <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a> at the end of the 17th century by a grower from <a href="Tozeur">Tozeur</a> named Sidi Touati.
The Algerian Ministry of Agriculture has decided to act in order to reserve the Deglet Nour label to Algerian dates.
Production.
This <a href="cultivar">cultivar</a> of <a href="Phoenix%20dactylifera">date</a> is mainly grown in Algeria (<a href="Tolga%2C%20Algeria">Tolga</a>, <a href="Oued%20Righ">Oued Righ</a>), in Tunisia (in the areas of <a href="Djerid">Jérid</a> and <a href="Nefzaoua">Nefzaoua</a>), and in the United States (in <a href="California">California</a>, <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a> and <a href="Texas">Texas</a>) where this cultivar was brought at the beginning of the 20th century.
